text:
The **economy of Suriname** was largely dependent upon the exports of
aluminium oxide and small amounts of aluminium produced from bauxite mined in
the country. However, after the departure of Alcoa, the economy depended on
the exports of crude oil and gold. Suriname was ranked the 124th safest
investment destination in the world in the March 2011 Euromoney Country Risk
rankings.
openai_summarised_points: • The economy of Suriname was historically heavily reliant on the exportation of aluminium oxide and limited quantities of aluminium, both derived from bauxite mined within the country.
• Following the exit of the aluminium company Alcoa, Suriname's economic dependence shifted primarily to the export of crude oil and gold.
• In March 2011, Suriname was ranked as the 124th safest investment destination globally according to the Euromoney Country Risk rankings.

text:
A member of CARICOM, Suriname also exports in small numbers rice, shrimp,
timber, bananas, fruits, and vegetables. Fernandes Group is a soft drinks
company bottled by Coca-Cola world-wide.

Other agricultural products of Suriname palm kernels, coconuts, peanuts; beef,
chickens; forest products; shrimp.
openai_summarised_points: • Suriname is a member of the Caribbean Community (CARICOM), which influences its trade relationships and export activities.
• The country exports agricultural products in small quantities, including rice, shrimp, timber, bananas, various fruits, and vegetables.
• The Fernandes Group is a notable Surinamese company specializing in soft drinks, which are bottled and distributed globally by Coca-Cola.
• Additional agricultural products produced in Suriname include palm kernels, coconuts, and peanuts.
• Livestock farming in Suriname contributes beef and chickens to the agricultural sector.
• Suriname also utilizes its forest resources for various forest products.
• Shrimp is another significant product derived from Suriname’s agricultural and aquaculture activities.

text:
In 2018, Suriname produced 273 thousand tons of rice, 125 thousand tons of
sugar cane, in addition to smaller productions of other agricultural products,
such as banana (48 thousand tons), orange (19 thousand tons) and coconut (14
thousand tons).
openai_summarised_points: • In 2018, Suriname produced a total of 273 thousand tons of rice, marking it as a significant agricultural product within the country.
• During the same year, Suriname also produced 125 thousand tons of sugar cane, indicating its importance alongside rice in the agricultural sector.
• In addition to rice and sugar cane, Suriname's agricultural output in 2018 included smaller quantities of other products such as bananas, with a production volume of 48 thousand tons.
• Orange production in Suriname for 2018 amounted to 19 thousand tons, contributing to the diversity of the country's agricultural sector.
• Coconut production in Suriname in 2018 was recorded at 14 thousand tons, further exemplifying the range of agricultural commodities produced.

text:
Some big companies are getting the hardwood out of the jungle. However,
proposals for exploitation of the country's tropical forests and undeveloped
regions of the interior traditionally inhabited by indigenous and Maroon
communities have raised the concerns of environmentalists and human rights
activists both in Suriname and abroad. These opposing parties are not yet
strong in Suriname.
openai_summarised_points: • Several large companies are engaged in the extraction of hardwood from Suriname's jungle regions.
• There have been proposals to exploit the country's tropical forests and undeveloped interior areas, which are traditionally inhabited by indigenous and Maroon communities.
• These proposals have elicited concerns from environmentalists and human rights activists both within Suriname and internationally.
• Despite these concerns, the opposing groups advocating for environmental protection and human rights are not yet strong or influential within Suriname.

text:
State-owned banana producer Surland closed its doors on April 5, 2002, after
its inability to meet payroll expenses for the second month in a row; it is
still unclear if Surland will survive this crisis.

The banana producer Surland was remodeled as Stichting Behoud Bananen Sector
Suriname (SBBS). The rumour was that because of political differences Surland
was manipulated into shutting down. The SBBS had made bananas profitable for
the first time in 20 years. There is also wide production of plantains in
Suriname.
openai_summarised_points: • The state-owned banana producer Surland ceased operations on April 5, 2002, due to its failure to meet payroll expenses for the second consecutive month, creating uncertainty about the company's survival amid the crisis.
• Following the closure, Surland was restructured and renamed Stichting Behoud Bananen Sector Suriname (SBBS), an organization aimed at sustaining the banana sector in Suriname.
• There were rumors suggesting that political differences played a role in manipulating Surland into shutting down, indicating possible external influences on the company's closure.
• Under the management of SBBS, banana production became profitable for the first time in 20 years, marking a significant turnaround in the sector's economic viability.
• In addition to bananas, Suriname has a widespread cultivation of plantains, contributing to the country's agricultural production.

text:
Currently gold exports make up 60-80% of all exports earnings. In 2021 the
gold industry accounted for 8.5% of the GDP. The share of large-scale mining
in total gold production is 58% compared to 42% of small-scale mining. With an
export value of USD 1.83 billion in 2023, the gold sector makes an important
contribution to the economy.

In early 2025, Suriname’s gold industry faced significant scrutiny after
revelations of major oversight failures by the Foreign Currency Committee,
which monitors gold exports and foreign currency flows. Finance and Planning
Minister Stanley Raghoebarsing disclosed that a private plane carrying gold
with an official export permit had been intercepted, yet the shipment would
yield no state revenue. This incident exposed broader issues, including the
issuance of numerous opaque and unjustified export permits, some granted to
parties not actively exporting gold. Despite high gold prices and increased
mining activity, official gold export figures were abnormally low, and the
government estimated a loss of at least US$300 million in recent months. These
irregularities contributed to the depreciation of the Surinamese dollar and
rising foreign currency prices. The minister pledged to implement stricter
oversight and reforms.
openai_summarised_points: • Gold exports constitute between 60% and 80% of Suriname’s total export earnings, highlighting the sector's dominant role in the country’s trade balance.
• In 2021, the gold industry contributed 8.5% to Suriname’s Gross Domestic Product (GDP), underscoring its significance within the national economy.
• Large-scale mining operations account for 58% of Suriname’s total gold production, whereas small-scale mining contributes the remaining 42%.
• The gold sector’s export value reached USD 1.83 billion in 2023, demonstrating its substantial economic contribution and export revenue generation.

• In early 2025, Suriname’s gold industry came under intense scrutiny due to major oversight failures by the Foreign Currency Committee, the body responsible for monitoring gold exports and foreign currency flows.

• Finance and Planning Minister Stanley Raghoebarsing revealed that a private plane carrying gold with an official export permit was intercepted, but the shipment generated no revenue for the state, indicating irregularities in export processes.

• The incident exposed systemic issues including the issuance of numerous opaque and unjustified export permits, some of which were granted to entities not actively engaged in gold exporting activities.
• Despite elevated gold prices and increased mining activity, official gold export figures were anomalously low, suggesting discrepancies in reported data and actual exports.
• The government estimated a financial loss of at least US$300 million in recent months due to these irregularities in gold export monitoring and permit issuance.
• These oversight failures and export irregularities contributed to the depreciation of the Surinamese dollar and an increase in foreign currency prices, negatively impacting the national economy.
• Minister Stanley Raghoebarsing committed to implementing stricter oversight mechanisms and reforms to address the identified weaknesses in the gold export regulatory framework.

text:
The backbone of Suriname's economy was the export of aluminium oxide (alumina)
and small amounts of aluminium produced from bauxite mined in the country. In
1999, the aluminium smelter at Paranam was closed. In November 2015 Suralco
ceased the mining of bauxite completely.
openai_summarised_points: • The primary foundation of Suriname's economy was the export of aluminium oxide (alumina) and limited quantities of aluminium, both derived from bauxite mined within the country.
• In 1999, the aluminium smelter located at Paranam was permanently closed, marking a significant change in the country's aluminium production infrastructure.
• In November 2015, Suralco, the company responsible for bauxite mining in Suriname, completely ceased all bauxite mining operations.

text:
The exploration and exploitation of oil adds substantially to the economy of
Suriname at about 10% of the GDP. The national oil company, STAATSOLIE, is the
motor behind Suriname's oil industry. Their core business is oil extraction
and refining.

In 2012 STAATSOLIE produced 16,200 barrels (2,580 m3) a day. Staatsolie
currently refines 16,500 barrels a day at Tout Lui Faut refinery in the
District of Wanica. Furthermore, they own a 96 MW powerplant and a 189 MW
hydro powerplant. They also have their own retail gas stations under their
Gow2 brand. They also claim to be a well-established bunker supplier in the
Caribbean region.

In 2022 they reported revenue of USD 840 million. In that year their
contribution to the state treasury was USD 320 million. In 2023 they made
revenue of USD 722 million. The drop in revenue was because of the lower price
for oil per barrel that year. Their contribution to the Surinamese state
treasury was USD 335 million.

Other players in the off-shore oil industry in Suriname are Total Energies,
Apache, Shell and Petronas. These companies have signed product sharing
contracts with STAATSOLIE for the exploration and extraction of off-shore oil.
The first of these contracts was signed in 2015. In 2023 they signed three
more of such contracts.

In 2020 the first off-shore oil was found. Currently STAATSOLIE, local
partners and Surinamese companies, as well as the Surinamese government are
actively anticipating on the development of the off-shore oil industry. The
first production will start with the development of oil block 58 in 2028 in
which STAATSOLIE has a share of 20%. It's projected that Suriname will make
around USD 7 billion in the first five production years.
openai_summarised_points: • The oil sector contributes approximately 10% to Suriname's Gross Domestic Product (GDP), significantly bolstering the national economy.
• STAATSOLIE, the national oil company of Suriname, is the principal entity driving the country's oil industry, focusing primarily on oil extraction and refining activities.
• In 2012, STAATSOLIE produced 16,200 barrels of oil per day, equivalent to 2,580 cubic meters daily.
• STAATSOLIE operates the Tout Lui Faut refinery located in the District of Wanica, where it refines 16,500 barrels of oil per day.
• The company owns and manages a 96 megawatt (MW) power plant and a 189 MW hydroelectric power plant, contributing to Suriname’s energy infrastructure.
• STAATSOLIE also operates its own network of retail gas stations under the brand name Gow2.
• Additionally, STAATSOLIE is recognized as a well-established bunker fuel supplier within the Caribbean region.
• In 2022, STAATSOLIE reported total revenue of USD 840 million and contributed USD 320 million to the Surinamese state treasury.
• In 2023, the company’s revenue declined to USD 722 million due to lower oil prices per barrel, yet its contribution to the state treasury increased to USD 335 million.
• Other major companies involved in Suriname’s offshore oil sector include Total Energies, Apache, Shell, and Petronas.
• These international oil companies have entered into production sharing contracts with STAATSOLIE for offshore oil exploration and extraction; the first contract was signed in 2015.
• In 2023, three additional production sharing contracts were signed between STAATSOLIE and these foreign oil companies.
• The first offshore oil discovery in Suriname was made in 2020, marking a significant milestone in the country’s oil industry development.
• STAATSOLIE, along with local partners, Surinamese companies, and the government, is actively preparing for the expansion of the offshore oil sector.
• The initial offshore oil production is scheduled to commence with the development of oil block 58 in 2028, in which STAATSOLIE holds a 20% stake.
• It is projected that Suriname will generate approximately USD 7 billion in revenue during the first five years of offshore oil production.

text:
Moreover, in January 2002, the government renego STAATSOLIE and other local
players are anticipating on the development of the off-shore oil
industry.tiated civil servant wages (a significant part of the work force and
a significant portion of government expenditure), agreeing to raises as high
as 100%. Pending implementation of these wage increases and concerned that the
government may be unable to meet these increased expenses, the local currency
weakened from Sf 2200 in January 2002 to nearly Sf 2500 in April 2002. On
March 26, 2003, the Central Bank of Suriname (CBvS) adjusted the exchange rate
of the U.S. dollar. This action resulted in further devaluation of the
Surinamese guilder. The official exchange rate of the US$ was SF 2,650 for
selling and SF 2,600 for purchasing. With the official exchange rate, the CBvS
came closer to the exchange rate on the parallel market which sold the U.S.
dollar for SF 3,250.

With the beginning of 2004 the Surinamese dollar (SRD) was introduced with an
exchange rate of 1000 Surinamese gulden to 1 Surinamese dollar. Before 2004:
Surinamese gulden (SRG) = 100 cent, SRD 1 = SRG 1000; coins had extremely low
official value and a much higher collector's value; their official value has
now been multiplied by 1000: the value in SRD cent is equal to the former
value in SRG cent. The same applies for "currency notes" (SRG 1 and 2.50).

Surinamese guilders per US dollar - 2,346.75 (2002), 2,178.5 (2001), 1,322.47
(2000), 859.44 (1999), 401 (1998)
Note: during 1998, the exchange rate splintered into four distinct rates; in
January 1999 the government floated the guilder, but subsequently fixed it
when the black-market rate plunged; the government then allowed trading within
a band of SRG 500 around the official rate

Between 2004 and 2022, the value of the new Surinamese dollar (SRD) was set by
the central bank. The Central Bank of Suriname spent much of Suriname's
foreign currency reserves supporting the official exchange rates as inflation
and other factors caused the real value of the Surinamese dollar to decline
against other reserve currencies. As with the previous Surinamese guilder, the
difference between the official exchange rate and the decreasing real value of
the currency allowed black market currency trading to thrive. In June 2021,
the central bank devalued the SRD by 33% and announced the currency would
float freely. By June 2022, official exchange rates began to reflect the real
floating exchange rate.
openai_summarised_points: • In January 2002, the Surinamese government renegotiated civil servant wages, agreeing to increases as high as 100%, affecting a significant portion of the workforce and government expenditure.

• Following the wage increase agreement but prior to implementation, concerns about the government's ability to meet these expenses led to a weakening of the local currency from Sf 2200 in January 2002 to nearly Sf 2500 by April 2002.
• On March 26, 2003, the Central Bank of Suriname (CBvS) adjusted the exchange rate of the U.S. dollar, resulting in further devaluation of the Surinamese guilder.
• The official exchange rate set by CBvS in March 2003 was SF 2,650 for selling and SF 2,600 for purchasing one U.S. dollar.
• This official rate brought the CBvS exchange rate closer to the parallel market rate, where the U.S. dollar was sold for SF 3,250.
• At the beginning of 2004, Suriname introduced the Surinamese dollar (SRD) to replace the Surinamese guilder (SRG) at a conversion rate of 1000 SRG to 1 SRD.

• Prior to 2004, the Surinamese guilder was subdivided into 100 cents; with the introduction of the SRD, the value of coins and currency notes was effectively multiplied by 1000, so that the value in SRD cents equaled the former value in SRG cents.
• This revaluation applied to coins and currency notes, including denominations such as SRG 1 and SRG 2.50, which had previously held very low official value but higher collector's value.
• Historical exchange rates of Surinamese guilders per U.S. dollar were as follows: 401 in 1998, 859.44 in 1999, 1,322.47 in 2000, 2,178.5 in 2001, and 2,346.75 in 2002.
• In 1998, the exchange rate fragmented into four distinct rates; in January 1999, the government floated the guilder but later fixed it when the black-market rate dropped sharply.
• Subsequently, the government allowed currency trading within a band of SRG 500 around the official exchange rate.

• Between 2004 and 2022, the value of the Surinamese dollar (SRD) was controlled by the Central Bank of Suriname, which used much of the country’s foreign currency reserves to support official exchange rates.
• Inflation and other economic factors caused the real value of the SRD to decline against other reserve currencies during this period.

• The gap between the official exchange rate and the currency’s decreasing real value facilitated the growth of black market currency trading, similar to the situation under the previous Surinamese guilder.
• In June 2021, the Central Bank of Suriname devalued the SRD by 33% and announced that the currency would float freely thereafter.
• By June 2022, official exchange rates began to reflect the real floating exchange rate of the Surinamese dollar.

text:
As of February 2021, Suriname's external debt stands at US$4 billion. Of this
amount, the nation sought to restructure a total of US$675 million in loans.
Suriname retained French investment bank Lazard to act as its financial
advisor during the restructuring.
openai_summarised_points: • As of February 2021, Suriname's total external debt amounted to US$4 billion.
• Within this total debt, Suriname aimed to restructure loans totaling US$675 million.
• The government of Suriname engaged the French investment bank Lazard to serve as its financial advisor throughout the debt restructuring process.

text:
The Suriname Stock Exchange (SSX) is the stock exchange of Suriname. The
exchange was established in 1994 by the Association for Securities Trading in
Suriname (VvES), founded on January 1, 1994. Stock trading does not occur
daily but twice a month on the first and third Thursday. There are twelve
companies listed on the exchange.
openai_summarised_points: • The Suriname Stock Exchange (SSX) serves as the official stock exchange of Suriname.
• The SSX was established in the year 1994 by the Association for Securities Trading in Suriname (VvES).
• The Association for Securities Trading in Suriname (VvES) was founded on January 1, 1994.
• Stock trading on the Suriname Stock Exchange does not occur on a daily basis; instead, trading sessions are held twice a month.
• These trading sessions take place on the first and third Thursday of each month.
• There are a total of twelve companies currently listed on the Suriname Stock Exchange.

text:
In April 2025, Suriname experienced a significant rise in the price of the
euro, which reached SRD 41.33. Finance and Planning Minister Stanley
Raghoebarsing attributed the increase to international developments,
particularly the weakening of the U.S. dollar following new American trade
policies. On 3 April 2025, U.S. President Donald Trump announced a 10% tariff
on all imports and higher rates on goods from around 60 economies. These
measures, analysts noted, could trigger global economic disruptions.
Raghoebarsing emphasized that the euro surge was not due to domestic policy
and urged the public not to panic.
openai_summarised_points: • In April 2025, Suriname experienced a significant increase in the price of the euro, which reached SRD 41.33.
• Finance and Planning Minister Stanley Raghoebarsing attributed the euro price surge to international developments, specifically the weakening of the U.S. dollar.
• The weakening of the U.S. dollar was linked to new American trade policies announced by U.S. President Donald Trump on 3 April 2025.
• On 3 April 2025, President Donald Trump declared a 10% tariff on all imports and higher tariff rates on goods from approximately 60 economies.
• Analysts warned that these U.S. tariff measures could potentially trigger global economic disruptions.
• Minister Raghoebarsing stressed that the rise in the euro’s value was not caused by Suriname’s domestic economic policies.
• Raghoebarsing urged the Surinamese public to remain calm and avoid panic in response to the currency fluctuations.

text:
The Suriname-Netherlands Chamber at the embassy of Suriname in The Hague

There are several Chambers of Commerce that are supporting the economy. The
general Chamber of Commerce and Factories (KKF) is located in Paramaribo. It
was founded on 1 May 1910 and has nearly 30,000 members in 2019 that provide
more than 150,000 jobs. Next to that, there are several international
Chambers. One of them is the Suriname-Netherlands Chamber of Commerce that is
established at the embassy of Suriname in The Hague. At the Chamber it is
possible to found a Surinamese company in the Netherlands. Furthermore there
is a Suriname-Guyana Chamber of Commerce, a Suriname-India Chamber of Commerce
and Industry and a Ghana-Suriname Chamber of Commerce.

In 2021 the government of Suriname founded the Suriname Investment and Trade
Agency (SITA) to support international investments in Suriname and exports of
Surinamese products abroad.
openai_summarised_points: • The general Chamber of Commerce and Factories (KKF) in Suriname, located in Paramaribo, was founded on 1 May 1910 and had nearly 30,000 members in 2019, collectively providing more than 150,000 jobs.
• Several international Chambers of Commerce support Suriname’s economy, including the Suriname-Netherlands Chamber of Commerce, which is established at the embassy of Suriname in The Hague.
• The Suriname-Netherlands Chamber of Commerce facilitates the founding of Surinamese companies in the Netherlands.
• Additional international Chambers include the Suriname-Guyana Chamber of Commerce, the Suriname-India Chamber of Commerce and Industry, and the Ghana-Suriname Chamber of Commerce.

• In 2021, the government of Suriname established the Suriname Investment and Trade Agency (SITA) to promote and support international investments in Suriname and to enhance exports of Surinamese products abroad.

• The GDP of Suriname in 1980 was 2.19 billion US$ PPP, with a nominal GDP of 1.28 billion US$, and experienced a real GDP growth rate of -6.5%; inflation, unemployment, and government debt data were not available for this year.

• From 1981 to 1989, Suriname's GDP (PPP) fluctuated between 2.29 billion and 2.79 billion US$, with real GDP growth rates ranging from -8.8% in 1987 to 10.8% in 1988; nominal GDP increased from 1.43 billion to 2.18 billion US$, but inflation, unemployment, and government debt data were not reported.

• In 1990, Suriname's GDP (PPP) was 2.85 billion US$ with a GDP per capita of 6,984.2 US$ PPP; nominal GDP was 0.58 billion US$ with a per capita of 1,413.6 US$; the real GDP growth rate was -1.5%, and government debt was 72.9% of GDP, while inflation and unemployment data were not available.

• Between 1991 and 1994, Suriname experienced volatile economic conditions: GDP (PPP) ranged from 2.54 to 2.70 billion US$, GDP per capita hovered around 6,100 to 6,440 US$ PPP, nominal GDP decreased from 0.64 to 0.52 billion US$, real GDP growth rates varied from -13.8% in 1991 to -7.0% in 1994, inflation surged from 14.0% to 255.8%, unemployment was 12.4% in 1994, and government debt declined from 75.7% to 30.5% of GDP.

• In 1995, the economy showed recovery with GDP (PPP) at 2.92 billion US$, GDP per capita of 6,676.7 US$ PPP, nominal GDP rising to 0.99 billion US$, real GDP growth of 11.3%, deflation of -49.3%, unemployment at 8.4%, and government debt at 16.3% of GDP.

• From 1996 to 1999, Suriname's GDP (PPP) increased steadily from 3.31 to 3.74 billion US$, GDP per capita rose from 7,470.8 to 8,103.4 US$ PPP, nominal GDP fluctuated between 1.23 and 1.31 billion US$, real GDP growth ranged from 11.2% to -0.9%, inflation varied widely from 4.2% to 71.9%, unemployment ranged from 8.4% to 12.0%, and government debt increased from 11.8% to 32.3% of GDP.

• In 2000, GDP (PPP) was 3.82 billion US$ with a GDP per capita of 8,180 US$ PPP; nominal GDP was 1.36 billion US$; real GDP growth was -0.1%, inflation was 44.7%, unemployment was 13.8%, and government debt was 35.7% of GDP.

• Between 2001 and 2005, Suriname's GDP (PPP) grew from 4.09 to 5.57 billion US$, GDP per capita increased from 8,646.6 to 11,171.8 US$ PPP, nominal GDP rose from 1.17 to 2.39 billion US$, real GDP growth fluctuated between 4.9% and 11.3%, inflation varied from 0.9% to 20.1%, unemployment ranged from 6.5% to 13.7%, and government debt decreased from 37.2% to 27.1% of GDP.

• From 2006 to 2010, GDP (PPP) increased from 6.07 to 7.68 billion US$, GDP per capita rose from 12,042.7 to 13,453.2 US$ PPP, nominal GDP grew from 2.81 to 4.68 billion US$, real GDP growth ranged from 3.0% to 5.8%, inflation varied between 1.3% and 10.3%, unemployment declined from 12.3% to 7.2%, and government debt fluctuated between 14.6% and 22.5% of GDP.

• In 2011 and 2012, Suriname's GDP (PPP) increased from 8.30 to 9.15 billion US$, GDP per capita rose from 15,363.4 to 16,889.6 US$ PPP, nominal GDP grew from 4.74 to 5.33 billion US$, real GDP growth slowed from 5.8% to 2.7%, inflation decreased from 5.2% to 4.3%, unemployment increased slightly from 7.5% to 8.1%, and government debt rose from 18.7% to 20.1% of GDP.

• In 2013 and 2014, GDP (PPP) increased from 9.85 to 10.23 billion US$, GDP per capita rose from 17,908.8 to 18,301.2 US$ PPP, nominal GDP grew from 5.51 to 5.61 billion US$, real GDP growth slowed to 0.3% in 2014, inflation remained low at 0.6% and 3.9%, unemployment decreased from 6.6% to 5.5%, and government debt fluctuated between 25.2% and 27.9% of GDP.

• The years 2015 and 2016 saw economic contraction with GDP (PPP) falling from 9.62 to 8.51 billion US$, GDP per capita declining from 16,962.5 to 14,777.8 US$ PPP, nominal GDP dropping from 5.13 to 3.32 billion US$, real GDP growth rates of -3.4% and -4.9%, inflation rising sharply to 25.1% and 52.4%, unemployment increasing from 7.0% to 10.0%, and government debt escalating from 41.1% to 74.8% of GDP.

• In 2017 and 2018, Suriname's GDP (PPP) rebounded to 10.23 and 9.62 billion US$, GDP per capita increased to 17,879.6 and 18,997.3 US$ PPP, nominal GDP rose to 3.59 and 4.00 billion US$, real GDP growth was 1.6% and 4.9%, inflation decreased to 9.3% and 5.4%, unemployment was 7.0% and 9.0%, and government debt declined from 71.5% to 66.1% of GDP.

• In 2019, GDP (PPP) declined to 8.51 billion US$ with a GDP per capita of 19,292.1 US$ PPP; nominal GDP was 3.98 billion US$; real GDP growth was 1.1%, inflation was 4.2%, unemployment was 8.8%, and government debt rose to 80.8% of GDP.

• The year 2020 marked a severe economic downturn with GDP (PPP) at 9.83 billion US$, GDP per capita at 16,311.2 US$ PPP, nominal GDP at 2.88 billion US$, real GDP contraction of -15.9%, inflation soaring to 60.7%, unemployment at 11.1%, and government debt sharply increasing to 143.8% of GDP.

• In 2021, GDP (PPP) slightly increased to 9.99 billion US$, GDP per capita was 16,379.9 US$ PPP, nominal GDP was 2.99 billion US$, real GDP growth was -2.7%, inflation remained at 60.7%, unemployment was 11.2%, and government debt decreased to 117.0% of GDP.

• IMF staff estimates for 2022 project GDP (PPP) at 10.83 billion US$, GDP per capita at 17,549.9 US$ PPP, nominal GDP at 3.52 billion US$, real GDP growth of 1.3%, inflation at 54.6%, unemployment at 10.9%, and government debt at 123.2% of GDP.

• For 2023, GDP (PPP) is estimated at 11.51 billion US$, GDP per capita at 18,427.1 US$ PPP, nominal GDP at 3.47 billion US$, real GDP growth of 2.3%, inflation at 28.2%, unemployment at 10.6%, and government debt at 112.2% of GDP.

• Projections for 2024 indicate GDP (PPP) of 12.11 billion US$, GDP per capita of 19,871.4 US$ PPP, nominal GDP of 3.78 billion US$, real GDP growth of 3.0%, inflation at 15.1%, unemployment at 10.3%, and government debt at 103.2% of GDP.
• For 2025, GDP (PPP) is forecasted at 12.71 billion US$, GDP per

openai_summarised_points: • In 2018, Suriname achieved an electrification rate of 97.4% for its total population, with urban areas reaching 99% and rural areas 94.3%.
• As of 2020, Suriname's installed electricity generating capacity was 542,000 kW.
• Electricity consumption in Suriname was estimated at 2,938,391,000 kWh in 2019.
• Suriname did not export electricity in 2019, with exports recorded at 0 kWh.
• The country imported 808 million kWh of electricity in 2019.
• Transmission and distribution losses accounted for 234 million kWh of electricity in 2019.

• The composition of Suriname’s electricity generation capacity in 2020 was 40.5% from fossil fuels, 58.8% from hydroelectricity, 0.4% from solar energy, and 0.3% from biomass and waste, with no capacity from nuclear, wind, tide and wave, or geothermal sources.
• In 2020, Suriname reported no production, consumption, exports, or imports of coal and gas reserves.
• Suriname’s total petroleum production was estimated at 14,800 barrels per day (bbl/day) in 2021.
• Refined petroleum consumption was 15,800 bbl/day in 2019.
• Crude oil and lease condensate exports were zero bbl/day in 2018, while imports were 200 bbl/day in the same year.
• Estimated crude oil reserves in Suriname stood at 89 million barrels in 2021.
• In 2015, Suriname produced 7,571 bbl/day of refined petroleum products, ranking 101st globally.
• Refined petroleum product exports were 14,000 bbl/day in 2015, placing Suriname 74th worldwide.
• Refined petroleum product imports were 10,700 bbl/day in 2015, with a global ranking of 145.
• Suriname’s carbon dioxide emissions totaled 2.372 million metric tonnes in 2019.
• Emissions from coal and metallurgical coke were zero metric tonnes of CO2 in 2019.
• Emissions from petroleum and other liquids accounted for 2.361 million metric tonnes of CO2 in 2019.
• Emissions from consumed natural gas were 11,000 metric tonnes of CO2 in 2019.
• Suriname ranked 156th globally in carbon dioxide emissions in 2019.
• Energy consumption per capita in Suriname was 82.356 million British thermal units (Btu) per person in 2019, ranking 71st in the world.
